did.abstract: Collection consists of letters to Amanda E. Edney, later Amanda Gardner, from her friend Mary Serina Harris, her children, and many others. The correspondence contains comments on social life and customs in the antebellum South; discussions of "Nullifiers" in North Carolina; descriptions by Mary of Florida with references to the dangers from Indians and to the climate; letters about E. Gardner's work at the Greenville Land Office; and her daughter Elizabeth's education at Presbyterian Female Collegiate Institute, Talladega, Ala., 1854-1855. Civil War letters from her son, John A. Gardner, a Confederate soldier, describe a military skirmish, the first battle of Manassas (1st Bull Run), camp life, illness, Confederate censorship, hospitals, the election of regimental officers, wages, and conscriptions. A letter from Dr. Thomas Hunter tells of John's death in 1862. A March 1865 letter from C. W. Hayes thanks Amanda Gardner for loaning books to the Union prisoners at Fort Morgan, Mobile, Alabama.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Amanda Gardner was originally from Yorkville, S.C., and moved to Edneyville, N.C. and Pleasant Hill, Ala., where she married E. Gardner in the early 1840s. The Gardners eventually moved to Cahaba, Alabama. The couple had at least two children: Elizabeth "Lizzie" Gardner, who attended Presbyterian Female Collegiate Institute in Alabama but died in either 1855 or 1856; and John A. Gardner, who served under Robert Rodes in an Alabama regiment of the Confederate Army, but who died in the Battle of Seven Pines in 1862.
